T01.G2.01.skill_name: Find actions that repeat in everyday tasks
T01.G2.01.description: **Student task:** Look at pictures showing an everyday task. Which action happens over and over? **Example:** In cleaning up toys, "pick up toy" happens many times. _Implementation note: Highlight or MCQ. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01.__

T01.G2.02.description: **Student task:** Look at two sets of directions. Pick the one that uses "repeat ___ times" to say the same thing in fewer words. **Example:** "Walk 3 steps, walk 3 steps, walk 3 steps" vs "Repeat 'walk 3 steps' 3 times" _Implementation note: MCQ (long explicit vs "repeat" version). CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01, E2‑ALG‑PS‑03.__

T01.G2.03.skill_name: Replace repeated steps with a repeat instruction
T01.G2.03.description: **Student task:** Look at a long list of repeated steps. Rewrite it using "repeat ___ times" to make it shorter and clearer. **Example:** "Clap, clap, clap, clap" becomes "Repeat 'clap' 4 times" _Implementation note: Choose or assemble compressed description with "repeat." CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01, E2‑ALG‑PS‑03.__

T01.G2.04.description: Students match simple “If it is ___, then do ___” rules to images (rainy/sunny, door open/closed). _Implementation note: Visual MCQ. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01._

T01.G2.05.description: Students fill in missing condition or action in an if/then pair for a daily scenario. _Implementation note: Fill‑in with picture or word cards. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01._

T01.G2.06.skill_name: Choose the best if/then rule for a situation
T01.G2.06.description: Students choose which of several if/then statements fits a picture story. _Implementation note: MCQ; auto‑graded. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01._

T01.G2.07.skill_name: Trace an algorithm that uses an if/then choice
T01.G2.07.description: Students follow short number/picture algorithms with if/then and identify the final result. _Implementation note: Tracing + MCQ result. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01, E2‑ALG‑PS‑03._

T01.G2.08.skill_name: Trace an algorithm that uses "repeat ___ times"
T01.G2.08.description: Students compute total actions or final position for routines with "repeat 3 times." _Implementation note: Tracing + MCQ. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01, E2‑ALG‑PS‑03._

T01.G2.09.skill_name: Fix a wrong repeat count in an algorithm
T01.G2.09.description: Students adjust a repeat count that causes too many or too few repetitions. _Implementation note: Increase/decrease repeat number; auto‑graded via final outcome. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01, E2‑ALG‑PS‑03._

T01.G2.10.skill_name: Fix a wrong or missing if/then branch
T01.G2.10.description: Students correct an if/then rule that doesn’t match a picture situation. _Implementation note: MCQ or card swap. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01._

T01.G2.11.skill_name: Trace maze directions on a simple grid
T01.G2.11.description: Students see a character on a small grid and a sequence of “forward/left/right” arrows, then choose where the character ends up. _Implementation note: Path tracing with MCQ final position; auto‑graded by ending cell. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01, E2‑ALG‑PS‑03._

T01.G2.12.skill_name: Choose directions that reach the goal
T01.G2.12.description: Students see a start and goal on a grid and pick which of several arrow sequences reaches the goal without hitting a wall. _Implementation note: MCQ (choose arrow sequence); auto‑graded via simulation. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01, E2‑ALG‑PS‑03._

T01.G2.13.skill_name: Write directions to navigate a simple grid
T01.G2.13.description: Students create instructions by dragging and dropping “forward/left/right” arrow cards to move a character from start to finish. _Implementation note: Drag arrow cards; auto‑graded via simulation. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01, E2‑ALG‑PS‑03._

T01.G2.14.skill_name: Fix maze directions that miss the goal
T01.G2.14.description: Students correct a set of directions that doesn’t reach the goal or hits a wall. _Implementation note: Edit arrow sequence; auto‑graded via new simulation. CSTA: E2‑ALG‑AF‑01, E2‑ALG‑PS‑03._

T02.G2.01.skill_name: Turn a picture routine into labeled boxes
T02.G2.01.description: Students see a 3–4 picture routine and build a horizontal row of labeled boxes (“Step 1,” “Step 2,” “Step 3”) that describe each step in simple words or icons, using a simple box‑diagram layout (like instruction boxes on paper).

T02.G2.02.skill_name: Read a box diagram and choose the matching pictures
T02.G2.02.description: Students are given a 3–4 box “algorithm diagram” and must choose which picture sequence matches it.

T02.G2.03.skill_name: Trace a simple left‑to‑right instruction sequence
T02.G2.03.description: Students see a short row of instruction cards with arrows or move/say icons (3–6 steps, no choices or repeats) and predict where a character ends up or what message appears last.

T02.G2.04.skill_name: Reveal one instruction at a time and mark intermediate states
T02.G2.04.description: Students reveal one instruction card at a time in a left‑to‑right sequence and mark where the character is after each step (for example, on a number line or grid).

T02.G2.05.skill_name: Match a box diagram to a step sequence
T02.G2.05.description: Students match a simple 3–4 step box diagram to one of several written or picture‑card step sequences that carry out the same actions.

T02.G2.06.skill_name: Fix a sequencing error in a step sequence
T02.G2.06.description: Students are given a short left‑to‑right step sequence whose cards are out of order and reorder them to match a target picture or box diagram.

T03.G2.01.skill_name: Choose subtasks for a simple project idea
T03.G2.01.description: Students read or hear a small project idea (e.g., “Make a greeting card project”) and select which subtasks are needed (e.g., “draw background,” “add message,” “add sound”).

T03.G2.02.description: Students drag subtasks into groups like "art," "words," "sound" for a small project.

T03.G2.03.skill_name: Arrange subtasks into a reasonable order
T03.G2.03.description: Students take 4–5 subtasks and order them into a simple plan (e.g., plan → create → try it out).

T03.G2.04.skill_name: Use a checklist to track progress on a mini‑project
T03.G2.04.description: Students see a mini‑project checklist and must mark which subtasks are done based on a short story (“We already drew the characters and added sounds.”).

T04.G2.01.skill_name: Identify the repeating unit in a longer pattern
T04.G2.01.description: Students see a longer pattern like ABCABCABC and choose the “unit” that repeats.

T04.G2.02.skill_name: Spot repeated step sequences in everyday algorithms
T04.G2.02.description: Students read or see an everyday algorithm (e.g., "brush, rinse" repeated three times) and highlight the part that repeats, focusing on the *pattern unit* rather than the full routine.

T04.G2.03.skill_name: Compare a long explicit description vs a compressed “repeat” description
T04.G2.03.description: Students choose which of two algorithm descriptions is shorter/clearer: one with all steps written out vs one with “repeat 3 times,” treating both as *generic pattern descriptions* rather than complete plans for a specific task.

T04.G2.04.skill_name: Replace repeated steps with a "repeat ___ times" phrase
T04.G2.04.description: Students rewrite a long description by choosing a version that uses "repeat ___ times" correctly, focusing on the *mechanics* of compression that will later be applied to whole routines in T01.

T05.G2.01.skill_name: Match different users to different preferred designs
T05.G2.01.description: Students see three users (e.g., kid, adult, person with glasses) and match each to a preferred design (colorful icons, simple layout, high contrast).

T05.G2.02.skill_name: Identify features that make a design more accessible
T05.G2.02.description: Students select features like large buttons, captions, and audio instructions as "helps more people use this."

T05.G2.03.skill_name: Recognize when a situation could be simulated
T05.G2.03.description: Students see scenarios (traffic light, plant growth, simple weather) and choose which ones could be tried on a computer using pretend versions as a way to “try ideas safely” instead of in real life.

T05.G2.04.skill_name: Choose what to include in a very simple simulation
T05.G2.04.description: Students decide which 2–3 elements are important to include when they “pretend on a computer” (e.g., “rain” and “sun” for plant growth) so the model can help answer a simple question.

T12.G2.01.skill_name: Add a note to explain a section of a plan
T12.G2.01.description: Students add a short note near a group of steps to explain why that section is there (e.g., "These steps are to get ready," "These steps are to clean up"). This is an unplugged analogue of commenting and documenting parts of a project.

T12.G2.02.skill_name: Fix confusing labels on a plan
T12.G2.02.description: Students see a simple plan with section titles that are vague or unclear (e.g., "Stuff," "More things") and replace them with clearer titles that match the steps underneath (e.g., "Set up chairs," "Decorate the room"). This mirrors renaming confusing identifiers but stays at the level of everyday language.

T12.G2.03.skill_name: Use the same style for section titles
T12.G2.03.description: Students review several section titles for one plan (e.g., "Set up," "Playing the game," "Clean up time!") and adjust or choose options so they all follow a similar style (for example, all starting with action words). This builds awareness of consistent naming without introducing code vocabulary.

T12.G2.04.skill_name: Group related steps under a heading
T12.G2.04.description: Students see 2–3 headings (e.g., "Before class," "During class," "After class") and a mixed set of picture steps, then group each step under the heading where it belongs. This extends the Grade 1 idea of splitting lists into clearly labeled sections.

T13.G2.01.skill_name: Fix steps that use the wrong signal
T13.G2.01.description: Students examine instructions where a character is supposed to act on a certain signal (e.g., clap, whistle, or card color) but the written or picture steps mention the wrong signal. They identify and fix the signal in the instructions so the behavior matches the story.

T13.G2.02.skill_name: Trace a set of steps and predict behavior
T13.G2.02.description: Students "walk through" a simple set of instructions step by step, predicting what each step does and what the character or object will look like or where it will end up at the end. This mental tracing helps them spot logic errors before acting it out.

T13.G2.03.skill_name: Fix a repeated step that happens too many or too few times
T13.G2.03.description: Students modify instructions where an action repeats the wrong number of times (e.g., clap 2 times instead of 5, or march too many steps). They change the number of repeats so the behavior matches a picture or description.

T13.G2.04.skill_name: Add a simple check to see if steps worked
T13.G2.04.description: Students add a small "check" card or picture (e.g., a thumbs‑up or scoreboard picture) at a key point in a set of steps to show that something important has happened (like reaching a goal or using all the cards). This helps them see what is going on inside a longer routine.

T14.G2.01.description: Students look at a turn-based scene with multiple players or timers and determine whose turn it is or what happens next when a turn ends.

T14.G2.02.skill_name: Track lives and game over conditions
T14.G2.02.description: Students track a player's lives through a short picture story. They identify when a life is lost (touching a hazard) and when the game is over (lives reach zero).

T14.G2.03.description: Students identify the condition for moving to the next level (touch goal, collect items) and notice that later levels are usually different or harder.

T14.G2.04.description: Students order 3–4 picture cards showing a safe route through a level (jump over spikes, grab key, open door) to highlight planning before play.

T14.G2.05.description: Presented with a short brief (“Make it easier for new players”), students choose the change that best matches the goal (add another heart, remove a hazard, shorten timer) to understand balancing.

T15.G2.01.description: Students compare two animation sequences (represented by frame strips) and identify which one represents a faster or slower action based on the gap between positions.

T15.G2.02.description: In a story sequence, students identify the point where the location changes (e.g., from House to School).

T15.G2.03.description: Students identify the repeating part of an animation (e.g., Left foot, Right foot, Left foot, Right foot).

T20.G2.01.skill_name: Use repeat cards in an art recipe
T20.G2.01.description: Students compare two instruction sets for the same border: one long (“red square, red square, red square…”) and one that uses a repeat card (“repeat red square 4 times”). They choose the concise, accurate version.

T20.G2.02.description: Learners arrange tiles on one side of a line and then plan what tiles should appear on the other side so the design is symmetrical.

T20.G2.03.description: Students interpret a two-layer instruction (e.g., "repeat row A three times, then repeat row B once") to build a stacked design out of strips.

T20.G2.04.skill_name: Explain how a change affects the art
T20.G2.04.description: Students consider "what-if" prompts (e.g., "What happens if the second color changes from blue to green?") and explain how the final pattern would change.

T23.G2.01.skill_name: Pick the right sensor for a job
T23.G2.01.description: Students see short stories (e.g., "turn on light when someone claps," "open door when tag is tapped") and choose camera vs microphone vs touch sensor to solve each task.

T23.G2.02.skill_name: Spot when sensor data might be unclear
T23.G2.02.description: Students look at pairs of pictures (bright vs dark room for a camera, quiet vs noisy room for a mic) and pick which one makes it harder for the sensor to understand.

T23.G2.03.description: Students compare two toys/apps: one reacts only to a button press; another tries to recognize an animal sound. They choose which one is “guessing” from sensor input and which one is just following a direct button command.

T25.G2.01.skill_name: Choose labels for a category chart
T25.G2.01.description: Students study a picture-based bar chart and provide meaningful text labels (e.g., rename “Column A” to “Bananas”). This underscores the importance of descriptive labels.

T25.G2.02.skill_name: Translate between timeline, table, and sentence
T25.G2.02.description: Learners view a three-step story (wake up → eat breakfast → go to school) and encode it as (1) a timeline drawing, (2) a table with time + action, and (3) a narrative sentence. Emphasis is on seeing equivalence across forms.

T25.G2.03.skill_name: Pick the best representation for a question
T25.G2.03.description: Students match questions ("How many stickers?" "Which order do things happen?") to the most useful representation type, building judgement about data tools.

T25.G2.04.description: Learners create flashcards with two pieces of info (animal + habitat) to see how pairing attributes forms richer records.

T26.G2.01.description: Students categorize example data statements as “observed” (counting birds) or “asked” (favorite color), reinforcing method selection.

T26.G2.02.description: Learners create a simple table to log respondents' names and answers, showing why we store identifiers alongside data.

T26.G2.03.skill_name: Use timers to collect duration data
T26.G2.03.description: Students run a simple experiment (spin a top) and record each trial’s duration using a timer, highlighting measurement precision.

T26.G2.04.description: Learners see two surveys (3 responses vs 10) and explain why the larger one may be more reliable.

T27.G2.01.skill_name: Create bar charts with axes labels
T27.G2.01.description: Learners build a bar chart using physical materials or drawing tools with labeled axes, reinforcing representation clarity.

T27.G2.02.description: Students analyze a small line plot (temperature across 5 days) and answer what increased/decreased.

T27.G2.03.skill_name: Identify outliers in small data sets
T27.G2.03.description: Learners see lists like [3, 4, 3, 12] and explain why 12 is unusual, learning to flag anomalies.

T27.G2.04.skill_name: Decide if data answers the question asked
T27.G2.04.description: Students read a question ("Which snack is most popular?") and determine if the provided chart answers it or if more data is needed.

T28.G2.01.skill_name: Sort events into certain / possible / impossible
T28.G2.01.topic: T28 – Chance & Simulations: G2–8 Skill List
T28.G2.01.description: Students classify illustrated events (the sun rising, rolling a 7 on a six-sided die, drawing a red marble from a bag that only has red) using everyday language about certainty.

T28.G2.02.topic: T28 – Chance & Simulations: G2–8 Skill List
T28.G2.02.description: Learners use a physical or on-screen spinner template, run 10 spins, and record tallies with stickers or pictographs to see which color appears more often.

T28.G2.03.skill_name: Decide if a simple game is fair
T28.G2.03.topic: T28 – Chance & Simulations: G2–8 Skill List
T28.G2.03.description: Students compare two drawn spinners (equal vs uneven slices) and explain which is “fairer” when playing a game.

T28.G2.04.topic: T28 – Chance & Simulations: G2–8 Skill List
T28.G2.04.description: Learners make a prediction before each of five coin flips, then compare correct vs incorrect guesses to appreciate randomness.

T30.G2.01.description: Students match simplified analogies (brain, short-term memory, backpack) to CPU, RAM, and storage.

T30.G2.02.description: Learners arrange arrows showing how a key press travels to the CPU and then displays on screen.

T30.G2.03.description: Students decide which devices need cables (HDMI, USB) vs wireless (Bluetooth headphones) and give reasons (speed, mobility).

T30.G2.04.skill_name: Share best practices for caring for devices
T30.G2.04.description: Learners list simple habits (carry with two hands, clean hands, plug in gently) linking hardware care to digital responsibility.

T32.G2.01.description: Students use a guided template to build a safer password (animal + number + symbol) and explain why it’s stronger than “cat.”

T32.G2.02.description: Learners follow picture instructions to log out of a shared tablet/computer and explain why that matters.

T32.G2.03.description: Students choose how to respond to unkind messages (ignore/report) and discuss why kindness online matters.

T32.G2.04.skill_name: Describe basic device care for security
T32.G2.04.description: Learners list practices (keep passwords hidden, don’t leave device unattended) linking physical care to digital safety.

T34.G2.01.description: Students fill a chart showing how a task (taking photos, shopping, banking) was done before computers vs today.

T34.G2.02.description: Learners analyze a case (screen readers, online maps) and list groups that gained access.

T34.G2.03.description: Students write/draw a mini-bio of a person (famous or local) who uses tech to help others.

T35.G2.01.skill_name: Compare benefits and harms of a tech tool
T35.G2.01.description: Students list positives and negatives for tools like video sharing or messaging apps.

T35.G2.02.description: Learners design a simple daily routine that includes device time, outdoor play, meals, and sleep.

T35.G2.03.description: Students role-play responses (ignore, block, tell adult) and positive messages.

T36.G2.01.skill_name: Identify project roles in simple terms
T36.G2.01.description: Students match roles (story planner, builder, tester) to tasks in a CreatiCode project.

T36.G2.02.description: Learners build a picture schedule showing device time alongside reading, outside play, meals, and sleep.

T36.G2.03.description: Students write or draw how classmates contribute unique skills (drawing, building, storytelling) to a project.
